newsitem.title: VIETNAM: Vietnam's president in critical condition - sources.
newsitem.headline: Vietnam's president in critical condition - sources.

text.p: Vietnam's President Le Duc Anh is lying in a coma at the Hanoi 108 Army Hospital after suffering a brain haemorrhage about nine days ago, medical sources said on Sunday.

"Earlier in the week he'd been getting better, but in the last few days his condition became very serious," one source said, adding doctors were unwilling to operate on the 75-year-old general or move him as his condition was so bad.
That was at odds with a government source's comment on Saturday that Anh, one of the communist country's leadership troika, had begun to recover.
That source said said news reports indicating the situation was more serious were exaggerated and rumours that he was more seriously ill or had even died should not be believed.
There have been widely conflicting reports about Anh's condition over the past week.

Political sources and medical staff have said that Anh was paralysed down one side of his body by a stroke, while the government's only official comment has been that he is tired and is in need of some rest.
There has been no announcement that Anh's deputy, Nguyen Thi Binh will stand in -- constitutional procedure if the president is incapacitated -- or that any successor is being considered.

Anh, who holds a key position of influence over the military and security apparatus, is part of leadership triumvirate which includes Communist Party Secretary-General Do Muoi, 79, and reformist Prime Minister Vo Van Kiet, 73.
Analysts say Anh's departure could reopen an internal debate over leadership succession which had simmered ahead of a key Communist Party congress earlier this year.
